A piece of dress among the ancient Romans, consisting of a mantle, smaller and shorter than the pallium, and having a cowl or hood for the head attached to it. It was worn especially by women, particularly as a morning garment, and by mimes on the stage.
A hood used by women in the eighteenth century, and perhaps earlier, when traveling or exposed to the weather, the use of it depending on the style of head-dress or coiffure in fashion of the time.
A separate skirt fastened around the waist over the other dress, worn by women in riding.
A light wrap sometimes worn by women upon the head; a head-covering resembling a scarf rather than a hood, and usually knitted or crocheted of wool.
A loose open jacket for women, usually of silk or some rather thick material.
A sort of jacket with skirts or tails extending about to the knee, worn by women in the seventeenth century.
Unnatural sexual relations between women.
A thin woolen cloth with a smooth and glossy face, used especially for women's gowns.
A silk textile material made in India, with a glossy surface: it is used for women's clothes.
A diseased and unrestrainable venereal appetite in men, corresponding to nymphomania in women.
A light woolen stuff used for the linings of coats and for women's dresses.
A mantle or cloak for women's wear, made of a shawl, and usually very simple in its cut, having no sleeves, and often resembling the burnoose.
A textile of silk and wool used for dresses and parts of dresses for women. The material is soft and flexible, and is usually woven in designs of Oriental character.
A loose, light robe, worn by women: only in poetical use, without precise meaning.
A loose morning-gown worn by women about the middle of the eighteenth century. It was trimmed with cuffs and ruffles of lace.
A kind of false birth fabled to be produced by Dutch women from sitting over their stoves (Johnson)′ , hence, an abortive scheme or attempt.
An accumulation of fat on the buttocks of certain Africans, especially Hottentot women.
An outdoor game of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, generally played by women alone, but sometimes in company with men. See second quotation.
The character or quality of being strong-minded, especially as used of women.
Black sulphuret of antimony, used by Moslem and Hindu women for darkening the eyes. See kohl.
A many-colored wrap or rectangular piece of woolen cloth used by the Indian women of Bolivia for carrying their children on the back. Compare atado.
A member of a sect of the 7th century who condemned all intercourse with women.
A small flat curl worn by women on the temples.
A fine, corded dress-fabric for women's wear.
A member of the Carmelite order of women.
In Spanish-speaking countries, a slipper; in the Philippine Islands, a native slipper without a heel and with a very small upper which barely covers the toes: worn by women.
A long-term, intimate, sometimes discreetly sexual relationship between two women.
A man who ardently seeks the company and affection of women.
A chronic inflammation of the lachrymal and salivary glands, often accompanied by rheumatoid arthritis and the presence of autoantibodies in the blood, occurring chiefly among women.
Slang   The man who would make an ideal mate: "self-help guides for women in search of Mr. Right”  ( Los Angeles Times).
The administration of estrogen and progestin to women to relieve the symptoms of menopause, prevent osteoporosis, and reduce the risk of heart disease.

A psychophysiological disorder usually occurring in young women that is characterized by an abnormal fear of becoming obese, a distorted self-image, a persistent unwillingness to eat, and severe weight loss. It is often accompanied by self-induced vomiting, excessive exercise, malnutrition, amenorrhea, and other physiological changes.
A rectangular woolen or linen cloak worn by men and women in ancient Greece.
The traditional dress of Vietnamese women, consisting of a long tunic that is slit on the sides and worn over loose trousers.
Line of descent as traced through women on the maternal side of a family.
A long cotton outer garment, usually white, traditionally worn by Muslim women.

The doctrine of a modern religious pantheistical sect in Persia, which was founded, about 1844, by Mirza Ali Mohammed ibn Rabhik (1820 -- 1850), who assumed the title of Bab-ed-Din (Per., Gate of the Faith). Babism is a mixture of Mohammedan, Christian, Jewish, and Parsi elements. This doctrine forbids concubinage and polygamy, and frees women from many of the degradations imposed upon them among the orthodox Mohammedans. Mendicancy, the use of intoxicating liquors and drugs, and slave dealing, are forbidden; asceticism is discountenanced.
The practice of procuring women for the gratification of lust.
A small flat curl worn on the temple by women.
a fringe of hair or curls worn about the forehead by women.
A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn by women under the hair to stuff it out.
A preparation of antimony used by the women of Eastern nations to darken the eyelids and eyelashes.
A pimp; a kept gallant; a page who waited on loose women.
A long robe or tunic girded at the waist, worn by women in Scotland as late as 1740. Planché. Also airisad, airisard.
A kind of taffeta or plain silk, used for women's and also for men's wear in the eighteenth century and earlier.
A pouch or purse, often richly embroidered, carried at the girdle by persons of rank during the middle ages. The name is also given to a bag or pouch similarly worn by women at the present day.
A strip of plaited muslin or lace placed inside of the bottom of women's dresses to protect them from the floor.
A light mixed fabric of cotton and wool for women's dresses, commonly used for summer gowns before the introduction of barege.
An outer petticoat worn by Basque and Spanish women.
A patch or spot placed on the face to heighten beauty, as formerly practised by women; hence, something that heightens beauty by contrast; a foil.
A kind of jacket, made of an entire deer-skin, worn by the women of the Apaches. L. Hamilton, Mex. Handbook, p. 49.
A head-dress formerly worn by the women of the Irish peasantry, described as a kind of kerchief.
A peculiar wide form of sleeve formerly worn by women: so named from its resemblance to the full sleeve, drawn in at the wrist, worn by Anglican bishops.
A shade formerly worn by women on the front of a bonnet to protect the complexion from the sun; also, a large bonnet or broad-brimmed hat serving the same purpose.
A linen vestment similar to a rochet, formerly worn by women over their other clothing.
A small cap, usually made of muslin or lace and ribbons, worn at breakfast by married women.
A small comb used to secure the curls called buckles worn by women.
A projecting or puffed-out covering of gauze or linen for the breast, much worn by women about the middle of the eighteenth century.
A textile fabric for women's dresses, made with a soft and glossy surface, in imitation of cashmere.
A bridle with double reins used by women.
In India, a small circular ornament worn by women on the forehead, between the eyes. It may be of metal or fine stone, or merely a mark made with an unguent or cosmetic.
A sort of muffler worn by women in the time of Charles I.
In ancient Greek costume, a small mantle of light stuff, apparently a small chlæna, worn by women.
The practice of acting as, or the custom of having, a cicisbeo; the practice of dangling about women.
A wooden clog or patten worn by women in Egypt and the Levant.
A thin fabric of worsted and cotton, or worsted and silk, twilled on one side, used for women's dresses: used as a substitute for merino, and especially as a material for inexpensive mourning.
A man who meddles with the domestic affairs of women; a betty.
A fine thin silk material, used for women's ruchings, dresses, etc.
A part of the headdress worn by women with the coif in the seventeenth century.
A kerchief; a covering for the head worn by women; an inner linen cap.
A place where poor women may leave their children to be taken care of during the day, while the mothers are at work.
A form of girdle worn by women in the sixteenth century.
An ornamental band or collar made of metal, beads, velvet, etc., and worn close round the throat by women.
In India, a wide piece of stuff, worn as a shawl, without cutting or sewing. It is the principal garment of women of the lower orders.
A loose upper garment of washable material worn by women while dressing. Also dressing-sack.
An outer garment worn by Maltese women, usually made of silk. See the extracts.
Women collectively; especially, the Amazons.
A chain of gold, usually set with jewels, worn on the head by women.
A kind of pinner attached to the cap or bonnet worn by women toward the close of the seventeenth century.
A loose garment with large sleeves worn by women in the sixteenth century. Also flokkard.

A cap or head-dress formerly worn by elderly women, formed like two crescents conjoined, and, by means of wire, made to stand out from the cushion on which the hair was dressed. Its name seems to come from the resemblance of its sides to wings.
In the fourteenth century and later, an outer garment used to protect the dress when riding. Apparently it was used by women only, and was the original of the modern riding-habit.
A band surrounding the forehead, worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, either alone or in combination with a cap or the like: said to have been used to prevent wrinkles.
An ornamental plaiting used for the frills and borders of women's caps, etc.
A bracelet of lacquered work, richly colored, and decorated with tin-foil, worn by women in India.
An anemic disease of young women, giving a greenish tinge to the complexion; chlorosis.
Drink, as ale or spirits, provided against a woman's confinement, and drunk by the women assembled on the occasion.
The sacrifice of women.
A light broadcloth especially adapted for women's riding-habits, but often, used for other outer garments.
One who makes habits; specifically, a maker of women's riding-habits.
A garment of muslin or similar material worn by women on the neck and shoulders, under the dress, usually having some resemblance to the collar, shirt-bosom, etc., worn by men.
A garment worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
A kerchief or other garment of linen for the head, worn especially by women.
A veil used to cover the head and usually falling behind it, as distinguished from the face-veil: such a veil is an important part of the costume of the wealthier Moslem women.
A man who meddles in women's affairs; a cotquean.
An outer garment worn by women in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, varying with the fashion, but generally a sort of close-fitting basque with short skirts.
An outer jacket worn by women; a sort of bodice without whalebone.
A lace used in the modern costume of the women of Holland.
A skirt somewhat shorter than a petticoat, worn by women when doing household work.
A plain glossy kind of silk formerly used for women's dresses.
A stiff flaring collar wired to stand up at the back of the head, worn by men and women in the 16th and early 17th century.
A painful swelling of the leg occurring in women after childbirth as a result of clotting and inflammation of the femoral veins.

Any of several connective tissue disorders, especially systemic lupus erythematosus, that primarily affect women of childbearing age, have a variety of clinical forms, and are characterized by red scaly skin lesions.
A sudden brief sensation of heat, often over the entire body, caused by a transient dilation of the blood vessels of the skin and experienced by some women during menopause.
Fear of or contempt for women.

An acute infection characterized by high fever, a sunburnlike rash, vomiting, and diarrhea, followed in severe cases by shock, that is caused by a toxin-producing strain of the common bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, occurring chiefly among young menstruating women who use vaginal tampons.

An abnormal curvature of the spine that is primarily manifested as a rounded hump in the upper back. Typically affecting older women, the curvature is a result of collapse of the spinal column, caused by osteoporosis.
A support, such as a hoop, worn beneath a skirt to extend it horizontally from the waist, used by European women in the 16th and 17th centuries.
Long underpants trimmed with ruffles extending below the skirt, worn by women in the mid-19th century. Often used in the plural.
A garment consisting of a rectangular piece of printed cloth worn especially in Polynesia by men and women as a wraparound skirt.
A garment worn by women as a blouse front under a sweater or jacket.
February 15, observed in the United States in commemoration of the birth in 1820 of the women's suffrage leader and feminist Susan B. Anthony.
A member of the Women in the Air Force, organized after World War II, but now no longer a separate branch.
January 20th, considered especially in the British Isles to be the night on which young women dream of their future husbands.
Greek Mythology   The goddess of women, marriage, and childbirth; the wife and sister of Zeus.
The language of the Chukchi, noted for being pronounced differently by men and women.
A movement in support of women's rights, especially the mid-twentieth century movement in North America and Europe.
A restroom for women.
Clothing for women.
A small handbag or case used by women for carrying cosmetics or toiletries.
The slight projection at the front of the throat formed by the largest cartilage of the larynx, usually more prominent in men than in women.
A bar patronized especially by unmarried men and women.
A set of principles applying the same standard to everyone, especially a moral code regarding the sexual behavior of both men and women.
A group of people, especially women, who meet regularly for the purpose of sewing, often for charitable causes.
A person considered inferior in status or rights in comparison with some others: "He believes women . . . are second-class citizens under the Constitution”  ( Edward M. Kennedy).
An extra large or oversize clothing size, especially one for women's or children's clothing.
A ruffle or pleat of lace, muslin, or other fine fabric used for trimming women's garments.
A man who enjoys and attracts the company of women.

a day regarded as terminating a quarter of the year; hence, one on which any payment, especially rent, becomes due. In matters influenced by United States statutes, quarter days are the first days of January, April, July, and October. In New York and many other places, as between landlord and tenant, they are the first days of May, August, November, and February. The quarter days usually recognized in England are 25th of March (Lady Day), the 24th of June (Midsummer Day), the 29th of September (Michaelmas Day), and the 25th of December (Christmas Day).

an enlisted man who handles his unit's administrative matters after hours
a negative term for a homosexual man who chooses not to reveal his sexual orientation
an enlisted man of the lowest rank in the Army or Marines
a man who is much concerned with his dress and appearance
A man of straw. See man of straw , under man.
A man of fashion given to pleasuring or sport; a fashionable man about town; esp., a man of means who drives his own horse, sails his own yacht, or the like.
In mining, the man who uses a tubber. Also called beele-man.
A man who practises obi. Also obea-man, obeah-man.
A man of literary culture; a man of letters; a literary man.
A hominiform or man-like ape: a hypothetical animal of higher brain-capacity than the anthropoid apes, but lower than the average in man, yet approaching man in erect gait. See Pithecanthropus, 1.
A descendant of Ishmael (the son of Abraham and Hagar), of whom it was said, “His hand will be against every man, and every man's hand against him.”

a genus of non-motile, rod-shaped Gram-positive bacteria of the family Corynebacteriaceae. They are facultatively anaerobic and produce acid but no gas from glucose. Members of this genus are parasitic on fish, birds, and mammals, including man. The type species of the genus, Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, causes erysipeloid in man.
A learned man; a man acquainted with literature; -- chiefly used in the plural.
See Portuguese man-of-war under man-of-war and also see Physalia.
Same as man of action.
The early orchis, Orchis muscula of England, so called from the color and shape of the tubers. Also called dead-man's-hand.
The fringe-tree, Chiomanthus Virginica. Also called old-man's-beard.
In mining, a bottom-man; a man who puts mine-cars on a cage.
Same as odd-man-out.
Same as tongue-man.
A word occurring only in the proverb “Better be an old man's darling than a young man's warling,” Camden, Remains.
A man having a white or gray beard; a gray beard; an old man.
Same as medicine-man.
A kind of car used for transporting miners up and down the steeply inclined shafts of some mines on Lake Superior. Compare man-engine.
One who deals in goods for men's wear. Also called man-huckster.
An inhabitant of the Isle of Man; a Manx man or woman.
An enlisted man belonging to a man-of-war.
The rate of work done normally by one man in a given time.—2. A motor utilizing the force of a man in driving machinery.
The worship of man; undue reverence or extreme adulation paid to a man.
A man of the Isle of Man. See Manx, n., 2.
Same as old-man cactus. See Cereus.
See man.
A man who sells pies; also, a man who makes pies.
In rhetoric, repetition of a word one or more times in close succession; especially, such repetition with a change of meaning or application: as, a man should be a man.
A man detailed to assist in working the sails of a man-of-war in action.
Same as sallee-man, 2.
A man; a laboring man.
One of a number of boys on board a man-of-war appointed to attend at the gangway and hand the man-ropes to an officer entering or leaving the ship.
The habit of considering everything as subordinate to man, or of considering things in relation to man and his needs and destiny.

A man who has a crucial, often hazardous role in the forefront of an enterprise: "[He] has traditionally been the administration's point man on affirmative-action issues, making frequent public appearances to present and clarify the administration's views”  ( Christian Science Monitor).
A man sphinx; a sphinx having the head of a man and the body of a lion.
Anthropology; the biology of man; the life-history of man, in a broad sense.
A man who wears an apron; a laboring man or workman; a waiter or bar-tender.
A man skilled in an art or in the arts; especially, a learned man; a scholar.
A warrior; a hero; a man of valor; in later use, a poetic term for man.
A rag man, or a man made of rags—that is, a scarecrow made of old garments.
Same as fasting-man.
On a man-of-war, a man stationed at the foremast to keep the ropes, etc., in order.
A man employed to do various kinds of work; a general-utility man; specifically, a skilled laborer who serves as assistant to a mechanic or artisan.
A book on a man-of-war which shows the length of liberty allowed, the time of returning, and the condition in which the man returned.
Plural of man-of-war.
Plural of man-child.
Plural of man-at-arms.
Basketball   An aggressive defensive strategy in which one or two players harass the ball handler in the backcourt while the rest of the team maintains a close man-to-man or zone defense.
early man of late Pleistocene; skull resembles that of Neanderthal man but with smaller cranial capacity; found in Java
modern man and extinct immediate ancestors of man
former genus of primitive man; now Homo soloensis: comprises Solo man
modern man and extinct immediate ancestors of man
former genus of primitive man; now Homo soloensis: comprises Solo man
intercourse via the anus, committed by a man with a man or woman
intercourse via the anus, committed by a man with a man or woman

The tenets or doctrines of Faustus Socinus, an Italian theologian of the sixteenth century, who denied the Trinity, the deity of Christ, the personality of the Devil, the native and total depravity of man, the vicarious atonement, and the eternity of future punishment. His theory was, that Christ was a man divinely commissioned, who had no existence before he was conceived by the Virgin Mary; that human sin was the imitation of Adam's sin, and that human salvation was the imitation and adoption of Christ's virtue; that the Bible was to be interpreted by human reason; and that its language was metaphorical, and not to be taken literally.

The price of a man's head; a compensation paid of a man killed, partly to the king for the loss of a subject, partly to the lord of a vassal, and partly to the next of kin. It was paid by the murderer.

Haeckel's hypothetical “ape-man,” a conjectured genus of mammals, based upon the Pithecanthropus, or primitive speechless man, supposed to have made his appearance toward the close of the Tertiary epoch, in what is usually called the human form, but destitute of the power of framing and using speech, as well as of the capacities accompanying that faculty. Haeckel uses the terms Alalus and Pithecanthropus interchangeably.

In rhetoric, the substitution of an epithet, or of the appellative of some office, dignity, profession, science, or trade, for the true name of a person, as when his majesty is used for a king, his lordship for a nobleman, or the philosopher for Aristotle; conversely, the use of a proper noun in the place of a common noun: as, a Cato for a man of severe gravity, or a Solomon for a wise man.

In logic, a mnemonic name of an indirect mood of the first figure of syllogism, in which the two premises are universal affirmatives and the conclusion is a particular affirmative: as, Every animal is a substance; every man is an animal; therefore, some substance is a man. The name was probably invented by Petrus Hispanus. See bamalip and mood.
A man slave, or a man bound to service without wages. Also improperly written bondsman.
The devil's-apron, Laminaria digitata. Also called dead-man's-toe.

In Scots law, that part of a man's movable succession which he is entitled to dispose of by testament, or that which remains of the movables over and above what is due to the wife and children. Sometimes dead man's part.

In mining, a flat iron bar suspended by chains in a shaft so that it may be raised or lowered at pleasure, and used to support a man engaged in making repairs or changes in the pit-work. The man sits on the bar, and is supported in part by a strap which goes round his body under the arms.
Short for gaberlunyie-man.
A figure or effigy of a man made of straw; hence, a man without any substance or means; a dependent. Also jack of straw.

In old English law, the position of a man who is found at his place in the forest with a crossbow bent, or with a long-bow, ready to let fly at a deer, or standing near a tree with greyhounds in a leash ready to slip. This is one of the four presumptions that a man intends stealing the king's deer.

In grammar, a noun whose originally normal inflections have been disguised by phonetic changes, as by hidden umlaut, quasi-gemination of semi-vowels, contraction, etc., so that the resulting forms are irregular. An example is, in Anglo-Saxon, nominative man, dative men, plural men, whence English man, plural men.
A wild cress. Lepidium campestre, also called poor-man's-pepper, and more properly field-cress.
A written or printed paper given to a man-of-war's-man, on which is specified the date and period of his liberty. The possession of it insures him against arrest as a deserter.
In athletics, the man who has the farthest distance to go in a race, or the greatest handicap to overcome; a scratch-man.

A genus of trematode worms of the family Fasciolidæ. These worms are from 8 to 16 millimeters long and live as parasites in the lungs of man, cats, and various other mammals. In man, especially in Asia, they cause a parasitic hemoptysis, long mistaken for tuberculosis. The type is P. westermanii.

A very primitive type of man, regarded as a precursor of the actual or existing type. Such a type is considered by many to have existed in Pithecanthropos erectus (of which the remains have been discovered in Java), taken to be a primitive species of man differing from all known human races in traits which those races have in common, and in them resembling the apes.
Nautical, a man stationed to do duty in a top. In a man-of-war the topmen are divided into fore-, main-, and mizzen-topmen. Also topsman.
A British sailor; a man-of-war's-man.

In zoöl. and anatomy, a small cartilage or bone of man and some other mammals, recognizably distinct at an early period, subsequently fused with its surroundings, constituting one of the elements of the compound temporal bone, and in man situated at the root of the styloid process, in the course of the hyoidean arch.
A name of several species of Clematis, primarily the European C. Vitalba, the traveler's-joy, also called old-man's-beard, and sometimes hedge-vine, maiden's-honesty, smokewood.
a figure, usually of a man, on old clocks, which struck the time on the bell.
A name given to a free-booting, unenlisted, armed man or guerrilla.
An uxorious, effeminate, or spiritless man.
A man.
The bone or cartilage of the tarsus, which articulates with the fibula, and corresponds to the calcaneum in man and most mammals.
a man specially skilled in any art, handicraft, or trade, or who is an overseer, foreman, or employer.
Anything that is fit for eating; that which may be safely eaten by man.
A native or inhabitant of Ethiopia; also, in a general sense, a negro or black man.
a conception of a thing formed by the first or direct application of the mind to the individual object; an idea or image; as, man, stone.

The bone or cartilage between the radiale and ulnare in the carpus, and between the tibiale and fibulare in the tarsus. It corresponds to the lunar in the carpus, and to a part of the astragalus in the tarsus of man and most mammals.
The upper and outer element of periotic bone, -- in man forming a part of the temporal bone.
rent paid for the privilege of building on another man's land.

A follower of Marcion, a Gnostic of the second century, who adopted the Oriental notion of the two conflicting principles, and imagined that between them there existed a third power, neither wholly good nor evil, the Creator of the world and of man, and the God of the Jewish dispensation.
a conspicuous or eminent man.
an easement or servitude by which a man has the right to have the water flowing from his house fall on the land of his neighbor.
a genus of fleas including the stick-tight flea (Echidnophaga gallinacea), which is a serious pest in subtropical America, infesting poultry and frequently attacking man and domestic animals.
A manikin, or image, representing an animal, especially man, with the skin removed so that the muscles are exposed for purposes of study.
A man who carries logs.
A little man.
A mythical monster having the head of man (with horns) and the body of a lion and the tail of a scorpion.
A youth; a young man; a juvenile.
A man who deals in lace.
A spear bearer; a statue of a man holding a spear or in the attitude of a spear bearer. Several important sculptures of this subject existed in antiquity, copies of which remain to us.
One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.
A man-of-war having two gun decks.
an easement or servitude by which one man has a right to convey water in pipes through or over the estate of another.
A “man” or piece used in the game of draughts.
A man who carries or takes care of a light.
A man rope at the side of a ladder.
A boy or man that carried a link or torch to light passengers.

a contrivance by which miners ascend or descend in a shaft. It consists of a series of landings in the shaft and an equal number of shelves on a vertical rod which has an up and down motion equal to the distance between the successive landings. A man steps from a landing to a shelf and is lifted or lowered to the next landing, upon which he them steps, and so on, traveling by successive stages.

a bullet which will produce a sufficient shock to stop a soldier advancing in a charge; specif., a small-caliber bullet so modified as to expand when striking the human body, producing a severe wound which is also difficult to treat medically. Types of bullets called hollow-nosed bullets, soft-nosed bullets and hollow-point bullets are classed as man-stopping. The dumdum bullet or dumdum is another well-known variety. Such bullets were originally designed for wars with savage tribes.
A sum paid to a lord as a pecuniary compensation for killing his man (that is, his vassal, servant, or tenant).
One who is given to intemperance or bacchanalian excesses; a man habitually lewd; a libertine.
A man employed in decoying wild fowl.
A judge in the Isle of Man who decides controversies without process.
A half man.

A personal chattel which had caused the death of a person, and for that reason was given to God, that is, forfeited to the crown, to be applied to pious uses, and distributed in alms by the high almoner. Thus, if a cart ran over a man and killed him, it was forfeited as a deodand.
a genus comprising vectors of important diseases of man and animals.
a character in a play by James Kenney, entitled “Raising the wind.” The name is applied to any needy, tricky, constant borrower; a confidence man.
The man who heaves the lead.
People; a nation; a man.
The act or practice of justifying or confirming a man's veracity by the oath of others; -- called also wager of law. See purgation; also Wager of law, under wager.
One who considers; a man of reflection; a thinker.
A man that wears the horns; a cuckold.
A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., and was renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for a very rich man.
A box or platform near the top of a mast, esp. in whalers, to shelter the man on the lookout.
A man who lets horses and carriages for hire.
Certain species of nematodes of the genus Filaria, sometimes found in the blood of man, the horse, the dog, etc.
A man skilled or employed in handcraft.
a minute European mite (Leptus autumnalis), of a bright crimson color, which is troublesome by penetrating the skin of man and domestic animals; -- called also harvest louse, and harvest bug.
A man engaged in harvesting.
A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hit man.
through the whole length of a man; completely; throughout.
A slanderer working for political purposes to damage the reputation of an opponent; a hatchet man.
A youth between boy and man; an awkward, gawky young fellow .
Any animal of the family Hominidae, including modern man as well as extinct species of the genera Homo and Australopithecus.
any one of several species of blood-sucking leeches, which, in moist, tropical regions, live on land, and are often troublesome to man and beast.

one of a peculiar kind of defensive and offensive stinging cells, found in great numbers in all cœlenterates, and in a few animals of other groups. They are most highly developed in the tentacles of jellyfishes, hydroids, and Actiniæ. Each of these cells is filled with, fluid, and contains a long, slender, often barbed, hollow thread coiled up within it. When the cell contracts the thread is quickly ejected, being at the same time turned inside out. The thread is able to penetrate the flesh of various small, soft-bodied animals, and carries a subtle poison by which they are speedily paralyzed and killed. The threads, at the same time, hold the prey in position, attached to the tentacles. Some of the jellyfishes, as the Portuguese man-of-war, and Cyanea, are able to penetrate the human skin, and inflict painful stings in the same way. Called also nettling cell, cnida, cnidocell.
A thin lamina of gray matter in each cerebral hemisphere of the brain of man.
A genus of small beetles of many species. They and their larvæ feed on aphids or plant lice, and hence are of great benefit to man. Also called ladybirds and ladybugs.
A stern man.
The man who manipulates a grip.
a long and slender African nematoid worm (Filaria Medinensis) of a white color. It lives in the cellular tissue of man, beneath the skin, and produces painful sores.
A disease communicated to man from the lower animals. Hydrophobia and glanders are examples of zoönoses.
Animal pathology; the science of the diseases of animals, excepting man. See zoötherapy.
The psychology of animals other than man; that body of fact or doctrine respecting the minds or mental activities of animals which may be derived from the study of their instincts, habits, etc.
A muscle of the external ear of some animals, which arises from the zygoma and is inserted in the auricle; in man, the attrahens aurem.
A wretched or unfortunate man.
One of the bones of the tarsus which in man, forms the great bone of the heel; -- called also fibulare.
A south American tick of the genus Amblyomma. There are several species, very troublesome to man and beast.
A south American fresh water fish of the genus Serrasalmo of many species, remarkable for its voracity. When numerous they attack man or beast, often with fatal results.
A man who digs chalk.
The great muscle of the buttock in man and most mammals, and the corresponding muscle in many lower animals.
The habit, found among insects, of customarily feeding upon excrement. It also occurs as a pathological condition in man.
In Bunyan's ‘Holy War,’ one of the warriors of Diabolus (the Devil) in his attack on Mansoul (man's soul).
In horse-racing, the flag held by the man stationed at the distance-post. See distance, 3.
A portable frame for holding a drill, having, usually, a screw for feeding the drill; a portable drill; a frame for a ratchet-drill. This frame is often called in American shops an old man.
The habitable part of the world; the part of the world inhabited by man.
The opinion in moral theology that where the reasons for either of two opposed courses of action are equally balanced, a man may use his liberty to follow either.
The science of comparative technology, including the study of the technology of primitive man.
A man engaged in signaling moving railway-trains during fogs.
A man shipped before the mast; a forecastleman.
Nautical, the vernacular of the galley; the idioms of the cooking-quarters on a man-of-war.
A man placed in charge of a ship's gangway when in port.
Unconscious, automatic natural selection, in distinction from teleclexis, an intentional or artificial selection brought about by man.
The governor or head-man of a village or small town in the Philippines.
An advocate of the single gold standard in finance; a ‘gold man.’
The cottage of a cotter or grass-man.
Grease (see def. 3) produced in other animals or in man by inoculation from the horse.
In cricket, a man whose duty it is to keep a cricket-ground in condition for play. Also groundsman.
A man skilled in representing topography by means of hachures or contours on an engraved plate.
A fabulous animal, part man and part horse; a horse-centaur.
One of the seven beneficent beings of the Japanese pantheon: represented as a fat, smooth-faced man, with a protruding, naked abdomen, and usually carrying a big hempen bag.
A man engaged in raising and moving buildings by means of jack-screws and rollers moving upon prepared wooden ways.
Sudden attacks of extreme hunger in the horse: it occurs also, as a manifestation of epilepsy, in man.
Perfection to excess; perfection, in the parts or functions of animals or of man, which is considered to be beyond the limits of usefulness.
In base-ball, a base-man, short-stop, or pitcher when he is fielding the ball.
Specifically, a bookkeeper employed in inns to run up, increase, or inflame the bills of customers: called the inflamer of reckonings. Jonson introduces a man of this kind in “The New Inn.”
In rackets, the server; the man in.
An abbreviation of Instructor of Musketry; of Isle of Man.
A familiar name for an enlisted man in the navy.
A shaman or medicine-man of the Australian aborigines.
A brother-in-law; a male relative of a man who, after the latter′ s death, has the right, and the duty, to marry his widow.
An old English term for the junior lieutenant. on a man-of-war, whose duty it was to drill the crew in musket and broadsword exercise.
A man employed on a bathing-beach to guard against accidents to bathers.
A man employed in the life-saving service.
A ring which surrounds the macula or spot of most acute vision in man and some of the apes.
A deity regarded as being in form or origin or in other respects a man.
A man who resembles Mawworm, a character in Bickerstaffe's play “The Hypocrite,” 1769; a hypocritical pretender to sanctity.
The study of the causes, nature, and treatment of rumination in man.

A sexless, encysted stage of certain tapeworms, as Bothriocephalus. If imperfectly cooked fish infested with the parasite in this stage is eaten by man, the metacestode develops into the mature tapeworm. Also called plerocestode.
A native head-man, in the Tamil districts of Ceylon; a chief.
Domestic squabbling; the quarreling of man and wife.
The non-sexual sporulating stage of the malarial parasite as it occurs in man.
An effeminate fellow; a ladies' man.
A genus of fishes of the family Nomeidæ, found in warm seas, some of them living commonly among the tentacles of the Portuguese man-of-war.
A man who delivers to subscribers the successive numbers of a subscription-book that is issued in numbers.
A disease of the liver in man, dogs, cats, and some other animals, caused by the presence (in the bile-ducts) of flukes (trematodes) belonging to the genus Opistorchis.
An exterior intelligence; some being outside of man.
In Ireland, a man who lived in the English pale.
The science of the origin and descent of man, from his earliest appearance to the end of the prehistoric period: not in general use.
The manifestation, by the higher animals or by man, of mental traits which are regarded as evidence of inheritance from lower and simpler animals in the remote past.
A man who does the domestic work which is carried on in pantries.
A general term including all infections (cerebral as well as pulmonary) with lung-flukes (genus Paragonimus), such as pulmonary distomatosis or parasitic hemoptysis in man.
In shoemaking, the man who fits together with paste the parts of the boot-uppers for the machine.
In French and British Guiana, a witch-doctor; a soothsayer; a medicine-man; a conjurer. See piache.
A black pigment belonging to the melanins, which has been found in melanotic growths in man, and in the urine of the affected individuals.
A medicine-man or witch-doctor among the Indians of Central and South America. Also peai. See peaiman.
In Tasmania, a man who cuts Huon pine and brings it down to the coast.
Sagittal flattening of the upper part of the human femur, a condition found frequently in some races of man.
The solid elongate larva, with no bladder, of some cestodes, as Bothriocephalus latus, an intestinal parasite found in man and the dog. Compare plerocestoid.
In theology, the spirit; the highest in man and the seat of the divine indwelling, as distinguished from the soul, the seat of the natural human life.
A man who looks after ponies, or has charge of ponies in a caravan, etc.
The type of man which in the evolutionary scale first developed true human characteristics.
A Christmas or New Year's ceremony, in the Isle of Man; one who takes part in the ceremony. See the first extract.
A name given to a Barbary man-of-war.
As much or as many as will fill a quiver: generally used with allusion to Ps. cxxvii. 5: “Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them ”
Mil., a rear-rank man.
An idle, and frequently dissolute, man who lives on remittances from his home.
The Portuguese man-of-war, Physalia pelagica.
The man who is in charge of the trackmen employed on a section of a railroad and is responsible for the maintenance of way for his section.
A man who wears soap-locks; hence, a low fellow; a young rowdy or rough: as, “the soap-locks of the Bowery.”
The human body; man viewed from an anatomical point of view without regard to his psychic activities.
The description of the physical characteristics of the races of man.
The scientific study of the philosophies developed by the various races of man, from the most primitive tribes to the present civilized nations.
A sea-bladder; a Portuguese man-of-war, Physalia.
The shelter or hut of a stock-man in the bush.
Infection with nematoid worms of the genus Strongyloides, as Cochin China diarrhea in man.
A technical term of the scholastic philosophy, signifying the innate principle in the moral consciousness of every man, which directs him to good and restrains him from evil.
In forestry, a man who records or tallies the measurements of logs as they are called by the scaler.
Among the Chinook and other Indians of Washington and British Columbia, a supernatural spirit or power; the power of the medicine-man; magic.
Short for tambourine: referring to an end-man in a negro minstrel-show who plays on that instrument.
The study of the effect of geographical environment on the technic arts of man.
The God-man, that is, Christ, as uniting the divine and human natures.
The belief that animals are men capable of assuming animal forms, endowed with the powers of both the animal and the human being, and, therefore, more powerful than man.
The worship by primitive man of wild or venomous beasts.
The smallest and weakest of a litter of pigs, puppies, or the like; a runt. [New Eng.] —2. Hence a man who is stunted, physically and mentally.
Infection with intestinal whipworms belonging to the nematode genus Trichuris (Trichocephalus), as Trichuris trichiura, one of the most common intestinal parasites of man.
An old name for a waister on a British man-of-war.
A term used in the late South African republics to denote any white man in the country who is not a Boer.
The accumulated proverbs and superstitions relative to the weather, especially in its relation to man, animals, the stars, the moon, and plants.
A man who patrols irrigation ditches to keep them in order or repair. See ditch-rider. Also zangero.

The domestication of animals; the relations between man and animals which are found in various stages of culture, beginning with the hunting of animals, and developing through toleration of animals as neighbors to domestication.
A water-spirit of the Orkneys, fabled to appear sometimes as a little horse, at other times as a man covered with seaweed.
A nematode worm abounding in the mud in tanks in India, and believed to be the young of the Filaria or Dracunculus medinensis, or guinea-worm, a troublesome parasite on man. See guinea-worm.
A man ready in the quotation of texts, or too strict in adherence to the letter of texts.
Love to both God and man; the doctrines or tenets of the theophilanthropists. Also theophilanthropy.
The dissection of beasts; the anatomy of other animals than man; zoötomy.
The fungus Saccharomyces albicans, which produces the disease in man known as thrush.
A small occasional muscle of man, upon the lower part of the tibia.
A man who attends to the attiring of another; a dresser, especially in a theater; a valet.
A swift steam man-of-war, especially designed to overtake and capture torpedo-boats.
One of the line officers of a man-of-war whose special duty it is to supervise and care for the torpedoes and their fittings.
An intrinsic muscle of the windpipe. In man the name is applied to the set of circular or transverse muscular fibers.
A small anomalous muscle of man, which sometimes extends from a low cervical vertebra, as the sixth, to some part of the clavicle.
One who teaches others in some trade or mechanical art; a man who instructs boys in some kind of handicraft.
In the Isle of Man, a territorial division, of uncertain origin and purpose, subdivided into estates called quarterlands.
In law, an old writ which lay for a man claiming as heir to his grandfather's grandfather, to recover lands of which he had been deprived by an abatement happening on the ancestor's death.
The doctrine that man consists of body, soul, and spirit, or other three essentially different modes of substance.
A man who prepares tripe and hawks it about.
The lesser tuberosity of the head of the humerus, in man the site of the insertion of the sub-scapularis muscle. See trochiter, and cut under humerus.
In whale-fishing, a man whose place in a whale-boat is near the tub containing the whale-line, and whose business is to see that no entanglement of the line takes place.
A man who collects tolls at a turnpike or toll-gate.
The character or state of being unsearchable, or beyond the power of man to explore.
Lodging; entertainment for man and beast. Scott.
One who vaunts; a boaster; a braggart; a man given to vain ostentation.
A man summoned under a venire facias for jury service.
The act of putting to death every twentieth man.
A man of Wapping, a district of London along the Thames, near the Tower.
A man of Wapping, London.
An undetermined muscid fly occurring in Brazil, which is said to lay its eggs in the skin of man and animals, causing large swellings inhabited by the larva.
A gun fired at the changing of the watch, as in a fortress or garrison, or on board a man-of-war.
A mark worn on the right or the left arm of a man in the naval service according as he is stationed in the star board or the port watch.
One who wenches; a lewd man.
The exoccipital fissure of the cerebrum; one of the so-called ape-fissures, found in apes as well as in man.
A man employed on or about a wharf; one performing or having charge of work on a wharf.
A man who busies himself about household affairs or woman's work.
A man who knows his wife's infidelity and submits to it; a submissive cuckold.
A wild man of the woods; a satyr or faun. Representations of woodwoses often appear in heraldry as supporters.
A male child.
A male child nursed at the same breast as another, or reared by the same person, but not the offspring of the same parents.
your foster brother is a male who is not a son of your parents but who is raised by your parents
a youthful male person
a child who is male
a male person
an adult person who is male (as opposed to a woman)
an extremely talented young male person
a teenager or a young adult male
A male attendant on a tennis court who collects the ball when it is out of play.
a young male shop assistant
a male child (a familiar term of address to a boy)
the male of species Equus caballus
one of the two male reproductive glands that produce spermatozoa and secrete androgens
one of the two male reproductive glands that produce spermatozoa and secrete androgens
a male sworn (usually by a ceremony involving the mingling of blood) to treat another as his brother
Relation by the father's side only; descent from a common male ancestor and in the male line: distinct from cognation, which includes descent in both the male and the female lines.
See male.
A male falcon; especially, the male of the peregrine falcon.
Same as male.
The sex chromosome associated with male characteristics in mammals, not occurring in females and occurring with one X-chromosome in the male sex-chromosome pair.
male hawk especially male peregrine or gyrfalcon
someone who engages in anal copulation (especially a male who engages in anal copulation with another male)
the male reproductive cell; the male gamete
the male reproductive cell; the male gamete
orchid having both male and female flowers in the same raceme; when a sensitive projection at the base of the column of the male flower is touched the pollen is suddenly ejected
male sex hormone that is produced in the testes and responsible for typical male sexual characteristics
orchid having both male and female flowers in the same raceme; when a sensitive projection at the base of the column of the male flower is touched the pollen is suddenly ejected

a small hornless deer (Moschus moschiferus), which inhabits the elevated parts of Central Asia. The upper canine teeth of the male are developed into sharp tusks, curved downward. The male has scent bags on the belly, from which the musk of commerce is derived. The deer is yellow or red-brown above, whitish below. The pygmy musk deer are chevrotains, as the kanchil and napu.

In zoology, the branch of a gonoblastidium of a hydrozoan which bears male gonophores; a generative bud or medusiform zooid in which the male elements only are developed, as distinguished from a gynophore or female gonophore. See gynophore, and cut under gonoblastidium.
In zoology, development of male parts or maturation of male products in hermaphrodite animals before the development or maturation of those of the opposite sex.

A beetle of the genus Dynastes, having in the male sex a large up-curved horn on the head, resembling somewhat the horn of the rhinoceros, as well as a more or less developed prothoracic horn. The common rhinoceros-beetle of the United States, Dynastes tityus, the largest of the North American beetles, has two large horns directed forward, one arising from the thorax and one from the head, in the male beetle only. The general color is greenish-gray with black markings. and between this form and a uniform brown there are many gradations. The larva feeds in decaying stumps and logs. Both beetle and larva have a peculiarly disagreeable odor, which, when they are present in any number, becomes insupportable. D. hercules of South America is another rhinoceros-beetle, specifically called the Hercules-beetle, whose prothoracic horn is immensely long. See also cut under Hercules-beetle.
A spermatic duct, or spermduct; a male gonaduct or seminal passage; a hollow tubular or vesicular organ in the male, serving to convey or detain sperm or semen.

Gegenbaur's term for the claspers of male elasmobranchs, the long, cartilaginous projections from the base of the ventral fins. The forward shifting of the fin is partially arrested in the male owing to the development of the mixipterygium.
The body of an adult human male; -- a term used especially in art.
a male hare.

a species of finch (Padda oryzivora), native of Java, but very commonly kept as a cage bird; -- called also ricebird, and paddy bird. In the male the upper parts are glaucous gray, the head and tail black, the under parts delicate rose, and the cheeks white. The bill is large and red. A white variety is also kept as a cage bird.
A person who delivers the mail; -- also called a letter carrier. A male mail carrier is also called a mailman.

A large, handsome, black-and-white North American woodpecker (Campephilus principalis), having a large, sharp, ivory-colored beak. Its general color is glossy black, with white secondaries, and a white dorsal stripe. The male has a large, scarlet crest. It is now rare, and found only in the Gulf States and Cuba.
An unfledged or young male sparrow hawk.

Any one of two or three species of Australian birds of the genus Menura. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen tail feathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of a lyre. The common lyre bird (Menura superba), inhabiting New South Wales, is about the size of a grouse. Its general color is brown, with rufous color on the throat, wings, tail coverts and tail. Called also lyre pheasant and lyre-tail.
The male of the roe deer in its third year.
A male fox. See the Note under dog, n., 6.
A popular name for any society or club which meets for the practice of male part songs.
An orgasm in a male animal accompanied by the ejaculation of semen.
the act or process of demasculinizing; the removal of the testicles of a male animal.
A male fallow deer gelded.
a North American duck (Histrionicus histrionicus). The male is dark ash, curiously streaked with white.
The horn or antler of the hart, or male red deer.
a male fallow deer in its fifth year, when it attains its complete set of antlers.
word: a buck of the first head

definition: A young male fur seal, esp. one from three to six years old; -- called also bachelor, because prevented from breeding by the older full-grown males.
tropical bird of Northern South America (Rupicola rupicola), the male having brilliant red or orange plumage and an erectile disklike crest.
a male child.
The spermcell, or male seed-cell; a spermatozoön. Also zoösperm.
an African falcon (Melierax canorus or musicus). The male has the habit, remarkable in a bird of prey, of singing to his mate, while she is incubating.
A name given in Ceylon and southern India to the paradise flycatcher, Terpsiphone, the adult male of which is white and black.
Deprivation of some of the characteristics of a woman, with or without the assumption of some of those of the male sex.
In ornithology, having two male mates.
In the Arachnida, the opening of the male genital organs.
In entomol., the condition of certain male ants which fail to develop wings and resemble the worker-ants in form.
One of the active vermifuge principles found in the rhizome of the male fern.
A pair of anal organs which open or shut transversely and cross each other, as in the male of Raphidia. Kirby and Spence.
The male salmon during the breeding-season.
An American corruption, in Alaskan waters, of holostiak, a young male fur-seal. See holostiak.
A young male fur-seal; a bachelor seal. Compare holluschick.
A resinous substance found in the rhizome of the male fern; one of the active principles to which the vermifuge action of the raw product is supposedly due.
A male gametophyte when the sexes are diœciously separated.
The peculiar dwarf male plant of the Œ dogoniaccæ (which see).
A (purely hypothetical) somatic cell of a male organism, that produces spermatozoa as germ-cells.
A paternal name; a name derived from one's father or from one's ancestors in the male line.
The stage of social evolution in which family and clan names descend in the male line from father to son: in distinction from the metronymic stage. See metronymic, 2.
One of two membranous air-sacs connected with the ductus ejaculatorius of a male honey-bee.
A German male singing society or chorus.
The sound-organ of a male cicadid.
An abbreviation of the Latin sine mascula prole, without male issue.
The aster associated with the male pronucleus or head of the spermatozoön during the precleavage stages of the fertilized egg.
In a lathe, the male screw which moves the back-center backward and forward; the tail-piece.
Either of the shrubs Garrya elliptica and G. Fremontii: so called in allusion to the elegant drooping catkins of the male plant.
A small male hawk. See the quotation.
The male mistlethrush.
In surgery, a method of introducing a catheter into the male bladder, formerly in vogue, but now generally abandoned as dangerous.
The male children of Tyndareus—Castor and Pollux: a name applied to the electric discharge commonly known as St. Elmo's fire. See corposant.
A male sea-monster of human form; a sort of merman.
A genus of buprestid beetles, containing the single species X. brendeli, from Illinois, remarkable in that the male antennæ are flabellate, a unique structure in the family Buprestidæ.
The male widgeon or goldenhead, Mareca penelope.
An Australian honeysucker (Myzomela sanguineolata); -- so called from the bright red color of the male bird.
A rudimental antler of a young male of the red deer.
the male of a variety of the zebu, or Indian ox, considered sacred by the Hindus.
A male friend who attends upon a bridegroom and bride at their marriage; the “best man.”
A baboon (Gelada Ruppelli) of Abyssinia, remarkable for the length of the hair on the neck and shoulders of the adult male.
a large European moth (Hepialus humuli); so called from the white color of the male, and the peculiar hovering flight; -- called also great swift.
A male cat, esp. an old one. See 1st gib. n.
The male of the salmon.
the male of a jungle fowl.
In embryology, a “married” bisexed or duplex nucleus; the renovated nucleus of an ovum after its union with the male pronucleus or spermonucleus. See feminonucleus.
That which has or sheds milt; a male fish in breeding-time. Also melter.
The typical genus of Monocystidæ. M. agilis is found in the male organ of the earthworm.
The male moor-fowl.
The male capercaillie.
A common European fern, Aspidium Oreopteris, closely allied to the male-fern, A. Filix-mas.
A male teacher of music.
The representative genus of the family Nectariniidæ, in which the middle tail-feathers of the male are long-exserted. The species are African. N. famosa is an example. Cinnyris is a synonym.

A pin the outer end of which is left projecting, after the pin has been inserted, to form a nipple for the attachment of another part, or for some other purpose. The nipple is commonly provided with a male-screw thread.
The bleekbok of South Africa, Antilope scoparia or Scopophorus ourebi, about 2 feet high, of a pale-dun color, white below, with sharp strong annulated horns in the male, inhabiting open plains.

A small deer of the pampas of South America, Cariacus campestris, the male of which has antlers dichotomous at the end, and with a simple brow-snag.It is one of two species forming the subgenus Blastocerus.
In entomology, one of the sucking-disks or-cups on the lower surface of the tarsus of a male beetle of the genus Dytiscus, or other water-beetle.
A male that submits to the crime against nature; a catamite.
The so-called male coffee-berry.
In botany, the nonmotile male organ in the Florideæand Ascomycetes: the same, or nearly the same, as pollinodium.
A male ancestor three generations earlier than one's grandfather.
A genus of Trochilidæ, so called from the serration of the bill of the male; the saw-billed humming-birds, as the Brazilian
A seal of the genus Histriophoca, H. fasciata, the male of which is curiously banded with whitish on a dark ground, as if adorned with ribbons. It inhabits the North Pacific.
A male animal with one testicle removed or wanting. Also ridgeling, ridgling.
The male of the roe-deer; less properly, the roe-deer.
The cock of the plains; the male sage-grouse. See cut under Centrocercus.
A neck of a bottle, flask, etc., provided with a male screw for the reception of a screw-cap.
The male eider-duck.
The narwhal, Monodon monoceros: so called from the single horn-like tusk of the male, sometimes 8 feet long. See cuts under Monodon and narwhal.
The male fur-seal or seabear of Alaska, Callorhinus ursinus.
A male servant, or man-servant.
A male servant; a menial.
The male bobolink in full plumage: from the resemblance of the black and white coloration to that of the skunk. See bobolink.
The doctrine or body of facts and opinions regarding sperm, semen, or the male elements of procreation, as those of spermatogenesis or spermatogeny. Also spermology.

The theory or doctrine that the male sperm contains the whole germ of the future animal, which develops entirely from a spermatozoön, the ovum serving merely as a mold or matrix; animalculism. Also spermatism.
A male pronucleus. See masculonucleus, feminonucleus.
A small euphorbiaceous tree, Acalypha rubra, formerly of St. Helena, now extinct. It was a handsome tree, named from its pendent spikes of reddish male, flowers.
The male inflorescence of Sphagnum compared to a diminutive catkin.
Authority and rule by man; hence, society organized on the basis of male supremacy. Compare gynecocracy.
In botany, a male sexual cell.
Fear of or repugnance to the male sex.
A crystalline principle. C23H32O7, said to be poisonous, which is contained in the rhizome of the male-fern, Dryopteris (Aspidium) Filixmas.
A male cook.
A male singer.
Among the pagan Tagalogs, a sorceress or witch; also (in Spanish use), a male sorcerer or priest.
The male European robin, Erythacus rubecula. The name is most familiar in a nursery rime.
The male English sparrow, Passer domesticus.
Ecclesiastical   December 28, observed in commemoration of the slaughter of male infants in Bethlehem during Herod the Great's attempt to kill the infant Jesus.
Chiefly British   A fish-eating duck (Mergus merganser), the male of which has a glossy greenish-black head and a white body.
A male turkey.
A chickenlike North American game bird (Bonasa umbellus) having mottled brownish plumage and noted for the drumming sounds the male makes with its wings. Also called birch partridge.
A widely distributed bird (Phasianus colchicus) native to the Old World, the male of which has a long pointed tail, brightly colored plumage, and a white ring around the neck.
A frog (Ascaphus turei) of the Pacific Northwest, having in the male an external cloaca that resembles a tail and serves as a copulatory organ at breeding time.
An efficient, faithful male aide or employee.
A North American blackbird (Euphagus carolinus), the male of which has blue-black feathers in the spring that turn rust-colored in the fall.
A North American blackbird (Agelaius phoeniceus), the male of which has scarlet patches on the wings. Also called redwing.
In psychoanalysis, a subconscious sexual desire in a child, especially a male child, for the parent of the opposite sex, usually accompanied by hostility to the parent of the same sex.
A tanager (Piranga ludoviciana) of western North America, the male of which is yellow with a red head and a black back.
A New World bird (Piranga olivacea) the male of which has bright scarlet plumage with a black tail and wings.
A heavy-bodied North American hawk (Buteo jamaicensis) that feeds primarily on rodents and has a conspicuous reddish-brown tail in the male.
A small European duck (Anas querquedula) having a conspicuous white stripe over each eye and down the back of the head in the male.
Slang   A person, especially a male prostitute, who engages in or appears likely to engage in such acts.
A rather small, delicately formed Eurasian deer (Capreolus capreolus) having short branched antlers in the male and a brownish coat.
A brownish-gray deer (Odocoileus hemionus) of western North America, having long mulelike ears, large branching antlers in the male, and a black-tipped tail. Also called black-tailed deer.
An elastic support for the male genitals, worn especially in athletic or other strenuous activity. Also called jockstrap.
Any of various burrowing crabs of the genus Uca of coastal areas, the male of which has a greatly enlarged anterior claw.
Any of several African weaverbirds of the genus Vidua, the male of which grows long, drooping, predominantly black tail feathers during the breeding season. Also called widow bird.
A New World sandpiper (Calidris melanotos) with brownish streaks on the upper part of the breast. The male inflates its breast during courtship.
A waterfowl (Biziura lobata) of Australia, the male of which has a leathery chin lobe and emits a musky odor during the breeding season.

A large, nearly extinct woodpecker (Campephilus principalis) of the southern United States and Cuba, having black plumage, white wing patches, an ivory-colored bill, and a bright red crest in the male. Also called ivorybill.
A sapsucker (Sphyrapicus varius) having a yellowish belly and in the male a scarlet crown and throat.
A small freshwater duck (Anas crecca), the male of which has gray plumage, a brown head, and an iridescent green speculum.
A North American duck (Oxyura jamaicensis) having stiff pointed tail feathers and, in the male, brownish-red upper plumage and a black-and-white head. Also called sprigtail.
A brightly colored American duck (Aix sponsa) that nests in hollow trees and the male of which is noted for its large crest.
The embryonic duct of the mesonephros, which in the male becomes the vas deferens and in both sexes gives rise to the ureter.
A mecopterous insect of the family Panorpidae, having in the male of most species a curved genital structure that resembles the sting of a scorpion.
A male prostitute hired by telephone.
Bible   A member of the tribe of Levi but not descended from Aaron and, if male, chosen to assist the Temple priests.
The dissection of a human body, especially of a male; androtomy.
A spore of some algæ, which has male functions.
One of the mobile male reproductive bodies in the antheridia of cryptogams.
A male voice, the compass of which partakes of the common bass and the tenor, but which does not descend as low as the one, nor rise as high as the other.
In botany, the male organs of a flower; the assemblage of stamens.

A specialized group of four tentacles on the right side of some male cephalopods, as the nautilus, three of them having their sheaths united and the fourth standing alone. The structure is opposite to the spadix; hence the name.
In biology, a male genoblast.
The common male fern, Aspidium Filix-mas, from the basket-like form of its growth.

In veterinary surgery, an operation which consists in twisting the testicles of bulls and other male animals round the cord, so as to produce atrophy, but leave the scrotum intact: a form of castration or gelding.
A young male calf: often applied in contempt to persons.
A male calf.
A male cat; a tomcat.
A local Scotch name of the male of the common black-clawed sea-crab, Cancer pagurus.
A leading or male swan.
The male of the lobster.

A genus of botflies, of the family Œstridæ, the species of which infest the male genitals of squirrels, rabbits, and other animals. C. emasculator is an example, so called from the effect it produces.
A male daw; a jackdaw; hence, figuratively, an empty, chattering fellow.
A male ape.
A drone or male bee.
One of those cells of a honeycomb which are destined for the larvæ of male bees. The eggs are laid in these at a later period than in the worker-cells.

In English law, the right of the eldest coparcener, when an estate descends to daughters jointly for want of a male heir, to make the first choice in the division of the inheritance. Also spelled æsnecy.
A genus of pteropods, so called from its relation to Firola, but distinguished by the simple tail-fin and the presence of tentacles in the male.
A male child nourished or reared like an own son, though not such by birth.

In Günther's ichthyological system, a subgroup of Cyprinodontidæ carnivoræ, in which the anal fin of the male is not modified into an intromittent organ, and all the teeth are pointed. It includes the subfamily Fundulinæ and other cyprinodonts.
A company of singers organized to sing glees, part-songs, and the like, often of male voices only.
The male widgeon, Mareca penelope; the yellowpoll.
One of the basal abdominal feet of certain male crustaceans which are specialized as auxiliary reproductive organs, as one of the pair of penes of a crab.
A boy; a male servant.
Among whalers, the old male of the sperm-whale.
The male of the guinea-fowl.
The male black grouse. See blackcock.
A kind of sea-worm, as species of Nereis; a clam-worm, as N. virens, believed by fishermen to be the male of the long clam, Mya arenaria.
A spent male salmon whose jaws have become hooked.
An arrest of development of the male generative organs, the urethra being more or less extensively open along its under side. Also hypospadias.
A male intriguer.
A male ape.
A male hare.
A volatile oil derived from the male flowers of the fragrant screw-pine, Pandanus odoratissimus. Also ketgee-oil.
A large, high-finned killer-whale, supposed to be the male.
A male child.
The common linnet, Linota cannabina: from the yellowish coloration of the male.
A genus of Tetraonidæ, including the blackcock or black grouse, Lyrurus tetrix, in the male of which the tail is lyrate; the lyre-tailed grouse.
More rapid occurrence of climax and ejaculation in the male during sexual intercourse than he or his partner wishes.
Development of male secondary sexual characteristics.
The smaller of a pair of conjugating gametes, usually the male, in an organism that reproduces by heterogamy.
The slender tube formed by the pollen grain that penetrates an ovule and releases the male gametes.
A small Eurasian marsh bird (Panurus biarmicus), the male of which has mustachelike black markings.
The male heir to the British throne.
A small Old World thrush (Saxicola torquata) of open, grassy regions, the male of which has a black head, dark wings and tail, and chestnut underparts.
A nonmotile cell in red algae and certain lichens and fungi that functions as a male gamete.
An organ or a gland in which male gametes are formed, especially in invertebrate animals.
Any of the cells of the gonads in male organisms that are the progenitors of spermatocytes.
A small antelope (Raphicerus campestris) of southern and eastern Africa, having a brownish coat and short, pointed horns in the male and living chiefly in dry grasslands.
A male red deer in its fourth year.
Any of various birds of the family Paradisaeidae, native to New Guinea and adjacent islands, usually having brilliant plumage and long tail feathers in the male.
Informal   A male goat.
A small Eurasian deer (Dama dama) having a yellowish-red coat spotted with white in summer and broad, flattened antlers in the male.
The male monster, descended from Cain, slain by Beowulf in the Old English epic Beowulf.
A small Old World merganser (Mergus albellus), the male of which has white and black plumage and a white crest.
Anatomy   Either of two small compound racemose glands located on either side of the vaginal orifice that secrete a lubricating mucus and are homologous to the bulbourethral glands in the male.
An evergreen tree (Lithocarpus densiflorus) native to California and Oregon, having leathery leaves, erect male catkins, and tannin-yielding bark. Also called tanbark.
An Old World duck (Aythya fuligula) having a short plump body and a crest on its head, the male of which has mostly black plumage.

A deciduous, rapidly growing tree (Ailanthus altissima) native to China, having sweetish fetid male flowers and widely planted in the United States as a street tree because of its resistance to pollution, disease, and insects.
A procedure for separating sperm cells from the seminal fluid, used especially in the treatment of male infertility.
A North American sea duck (Melanitta perspicillata), the male of which is black with a white forehead and nape.
A North American bird (Pheucticus ludovicianus), the male of which is black and white with a rose-red patch on the breast.
The male sage grouse.
A small bird (Archilochus colubris) of eastern North America, having metallic-green upper plumage and, in the male, a brilliant red throat.
A hummingbird (Selasphorus rufus) of western North America, distributed from Mexico to Alaska, having rufous upper parts in the male.
A microspore of seed plants, containing a male gametophyte.
A North American duck (Aythya collaris) having a distinctive light ring behind the tip of the bill and, in the male, a light chestnut ring around the neck. Also called ring-bill.
The adult male fur seal of Alaska.
A small finch (Passerina ciris) of the southern United States and Mexico, the male of which has brilliant multicolored plumage. Also called nonpareil.
A small salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) of Pacific waters, the male of which has a pink color and a conspicuous dorsal hump during the spawning season. Also called humpback salmon.
The male red grouse.
The primary male member of a household.
One's best male friend.
A cell of the male gametophyte or pollen grain in seed plants that divides to give rise directly or indirectly to sperm.
A fast, elaborately choreographed Native American powwow dance performed by a costumed male dancer to a drum accompaniment.
Dull or colorless plumage that certain birds, such as male ducks, acquire at the end of the breeding season.
Either of two South American birds (Rupicola rupicola or R. peruviana) having a distinctive crest and bright-orange or reddish plumage in the male.
A male shaman or shamanistic healer, especially among Native American peoples.
Any of the four haploid cells formed by meiosis in a male organism that develop into spermatozoa without further division.
A small common finch (Passerina cyanea) of North and Central America, the male of which has deep blue plumage.
A small bird (Passer domesticus) native to the Old World but widely naturalized elsewhere, having brown and gray plumage with a black throat in the adult male. Also called English sparrow.
A genus of beautiful trees, natives of the East Indies. The tree imperfectly diœcious, and the staminate or male plant is very offensive when blossom.

an American song bird (Cardinalis cardinalis, or Cardinalis Virginianus), of the family Fringillidæ, or finches of which the male has a bright red plumage, and both sexes have a high, pointed crest on its head; -- it is also called the northern cardinal or eastern cardinal. The males have loud and musical notes resembling those of a fife. Other related species are also called cardinal birds.
a male ape.
the adult male singing voice above baritone
grasshoppers with long threadlike antennae and well-developed stridulating organs on the forewings of the male
small Atlantic wrasse the male of which has a brilliant blue head
offspring of a male tiger and a female lion
male turkey
townsman unacquainted with country life especially a slick and flashy male city dweller
European thrush common in rocky areas; the male has blackish plumage with a white band around the neck
a testis that fails to move into the scrotum as the male fetus develops
a testis that fails to move into the scrotum as the male fetus develops
tropical American flycatcher found as far north as southern Texas and Arizona; adult male has bright scarlet and black plumage
the abnormal development of male sexual characteristics in a female (usually as the result of hormone therapies or adrenal malfunction)
a male person assumed to have been raised by wolves
male wood duck
hereditary pattern in which a recessive gene on the X chromosome results in the manifestation of characteristics in male offspring and a carrier state in female offspring
SCID in male children resulting from mutation of a gene that codes for a protein on the surface of T cells that allows them to develop a growth factor receptor
SCID in male children resulting from mutation of a gene that codes for a protein on the surface of T cells that allows them to develop a growth factor receptor
(genetics) abnormal complement of sex hormones in a male resulting in Klinefelter's syndrome

syndrome in males that is characterized by small testes and long legs and enlarged breasts and reduced sperm production and mental retardation; a genetic defect in which an extra X chromosome (XXY) is present in the male
(genetics) abnormal complement of sex hormones in a male who has two Y chromosomes
European bunting the male being bright yellow
American finch whose male has yellow body plumage in summer
A male poster child.
A baboon (Papio hamadryas) of northern Africa and Arabia, the adult male of which has a heavy mane. Also called sacred baboon.
A male member of the armed forces who ranks below a commissioned officer or warrant officer.
An African gazelle (Litocranius walleri) having long legs, a long slender neck, and backward-curving horns in the male.
A relative on the father's or male side only.
A son or grandson of a czar in the male line.
The daughter or granddaughter of a czar in the male line.
Any of a group of elder male politicians of Japan who were formerly advisers to the emperor.
A marking that resembles an eye, as on the tail feathers of a male peacock; an eyespot.
The male heir apparent to a throne.
Either of two conjugating gametes that differ in structure or behavior, such as the small motile male spermatozoon and the larger nonmotile female ovum. Also called anisogamete.
Botany   The smaller of two types of spores that give rise to a male gametophyte.
Either of a pair of pouchlike glands situated on each side of the male urinary bladder that secrete seminal fluid and nourish and promote the movement of spermatozoa through the urethra.

Either of a pair of chromosomes, usually designated X or Y, in the germ cells of most animals and some plants, that combine to determine the sex and sex-linked characteristics of an individual, with XX resulting in a female and XY in a male in mammals.
An old custom in certain English boroughs whereby the right to inherit an estate intestate went to the youngest son or, in default of male issue, to the youngest brother.
An insect (Corydalus cornutus) having four large, many-veined wings and in the male long, pincerlike mandibles.
A gland in male mammals surrounding the urethra at the base of the bladder that controls release of urine from the bladder and secretes a fluid which is a major constituent of semen.
Either of two deciduous trees (Carya glabra or C. ovalis) of the eastern United States, having pinnately compound leaves, male flowers grouped in catkins, and nuts with somewhat bitter kernels.
large gregarious predatory feline of Africa and India having a tawny coat with a shaggy mane in the male

shrubby Asiatic tree having bark (tapa) that resembles cloth; grown as a shade tree in Europe and America; male flowers are pendulous catkins and female are urn-shaped followed by small orange-red aggregate berries
an index of the relation between any two sets of scores that can both be represented on ordered binary dimensions (e.g., male-female)
an index of the relation between any two sets of scores that can both be represented on ordered binary dimensions (e.g., male-female)
common Eurasian sandpiper; the male has an erectile neck ruff in breeding season
a male character in French pantomime; usually dressed in white with a whitened face
small dark-colored whale of the Atlantic coast of the United States; the largest male acts as pilot or leader for the school
of western North America; male is black and yellow and orange-red
the male is bright red with black wings and tail
of middle and southern United States; male is deep rose-red the female mostly yellow
the state of being potent; a male's capacity to have sexual intercourse
(classical mythology) god of male procreative power and guardian of gardens and vineyards
male deer in his second year
large North American martin of which the male is blue-black
of southeast Australia; male is glossy violet blue; female is light grey-green
large European butterfly the male of which has wings shaded with purple
tropical American flycatcher found as far north as southern Texas and Arizona; adult male has bright scarlet and black plumage
an all-male organization begun in 1925 to foster nationalism in India's Hindus
American kinglet with a notable song and in the male a red crown patch
crested thick-billed North American finch having bright red plumage in the male
European thrush common in rocky areas; the male has blackish plumage with a white band around the neck
European thrush common in rocky areas; the male has blackish plumage with a white band around the neck
European thrush common in rocky areas; the male has blackish plumage with a white band around the neck
American kinglet with a notable song and in the male a red crown patch
American kinglet with a notable song and in the male a red crown patch
tropical bird of northern South America the male having brilliant red or orange plumage and an erectile disklike crest
of southeast Australia; male is glossy violet blue; female is light grey-green
of southeast Australia; male is glossy violet blue; female is light grey-green
fertilization by the union of male and female gametes from the same individual
fertilization by the union of male and female gametes from the same individual
